channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: NHS concern genuine, says Lansley
item.description: Health Secretary Andrew Lansley acknowledges there are "genuine concerns" about the NHS shake-up in England - amid accusations the policy is in "chaos".

item.title: New Ivory Coast offensive begins
item.description: Forces loyal to internationally recognised Ivory Coast President Alassane Ouattara say they have launched a new offensive on Abidjan.

item.title: More RAF planes for Libya mission
item.description: Four more British warplanes are being deployed to join the assault on pro-Gaddafi forces in Libya, the prime minister announces in Italy.

item.title: Man found guilty of canal murders
item.description: A man is found guilty of murdering two women whose bodies were found mutilated and dumped in canals in London and the Netherlands.

item.title: Officer's murder was 'grotesque'
item.description: The police officer killed by a bomb in Omagh on Saturday was "brutally and grotesquely murdered", a detective leading the investigation says.

item.title: Obama announces re-election bid
item.description: US President Barack Obama releases an online video and e-mail announcing his intention to seek re-election in 2012.

item.title: Sian police identify second body
item.description: Police identify a woman whose remains were found at a field in Eastleach in Gloucestershire.

item.title: New state pension plans unveiled
item.description: Plans for a new flat-rate state pension and a system to automatically raise the pension age have been formally published.

item.title: 'Military trial' for 9/11 accused
item.description: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, alleged mastermind of the 9/11 attacks, and four alleged conspirators will be tried at Guantanamo Bay not a US court, reports say.

item.title: 2,600 Navy and Army posts to go
item.description: Some 1,600 Navy personnel and 1,000 soldiers are to be made redundant in the first tranche of Armed Forces redundancies, the government says.

item.title: Japan dumps radioactive water in sea
item.description: Workers at Japan's quake-hit nuclear plant dump water with low levels of contamination into the sea so more highly radioactive water can be stored.

item.title: Family walks out at G20 inquest
item.description: The wife of Ian Tomlinson, who died at the G20 protests in 2009 after he was pushed by a police officer, has walked out of his inquest.

item.title: Japan tsunami dog reunited with owner
item.description: A dog rescued from a roof drifting in the sea off Japan's north-east coast more than three weeks after an earthquake and tsunami is reunited with her owner.

item.title: Fulham's Michael Jackson statue - the critics react
item.description: Contemporary art critics give their verdict on the Michael Jackson statue unveiled at Fulham's Craven Cottage ground at the weekend.

item.title: Rooney faces two-match suspension
item.description: Wayne Rooney is charged by the FA for using offensive language during Manchester United's 4-2 win over West Ham.

item.title: Red Bull dismiss link to Hamilton
item.description: Red Bull team boss Christian Horner plays down speculation McLaren's Lewis Hamilton could join the team in the future.

item.title: West Ham examine race abuse claim
item.description: West Ham are investigating a report that the families of their players Victor Obinna and Frederic Piquionne were racially abused during the defeat by Manchester United on Saturday.

item.title: Ronaldo could play against Spurs
item.description: Real Madrid coach Jose Mourinho says Cristiano Ronaldo could play in the Champions League quarter-final first-leg tie against Tottenham.

item.title: Synchronised will miss National
item.description: Welsh National winner Synchronised is one of nine horses to be withdrawn from the field for the 2011 Grand National at Aintree on Saturday.

item.title: Fine over dishwasher fluid death
item.description: A county council is fined £50,000 following the death of a man with Down's syndrome after he drank dishwasher fluid on an outing.

item.title: M11 shut after nine-vehicle crash
item.description: The M11 in Essex is closed following a nine-vehicle crash which leaves five people injured.

item.title: Senior Lib Dem backs Alex Salmond
item.description: Veteran Liberal Democrat John Farquhar Munro has backed Alex Salmond for another term as first minister.

item.title: Tories detail education reforms
item.description: Lowering the school leaving age and introducing a capped graduate fee are among policies outlined in the Scottish Tory manifesto.

item.title: Murder 'won't destabilise peace'
item.description: Secretary of State for Northern Ireland Owen Paterson tells the House of Commons the murder of Ronan Kerr will not destabilise the peace process

item.title: Man, 18, in court over road death
item.description: An 18-year-old man appears in court accused of causing death by dangerous driving and driving while unfit through drink or drugs.

item.title: 'Smell of death' led to bodies
item.description: Two police dog handlers were led to the bodies of two murder victims on the Pembrokeshire coastal path by the "smell of death," a jury has heard.

item.title: Labour aims for assembly majority
item.description: A majority of seats in the assembly is within reach for Labour election day, Carwyn Jones says.

item.title: Abidjan facing 'rapid offensive'
item.description: A close aide of Ivory Coast's internationally recognised president, Alassane Ouattara, says the time is right for a "rapid offensive" against the country's main city, Abidjan.

item.title: Libya rebels resume Brega attack
item.description: Libyan rebels advance towards the oil town of Brega, reports say, as a senior Libyan envoy holds talks in Europe on behalf of Col Gaddafi.

item.title: France, Germany in artist appeal
item.description: France and Germany have called for the immediate release of Chinese artist and dissident Ai Weiwei, detained by authorities in Beijing as he tried to board a flight.

item.title: Saudi acquittal angers Indonesia
item.description: An Indonesian diplomat in Saudi Arabia criticises the overturning of a Saudi woman's three-year conviction for beating and torturing her Indonesian maid.

item.title: Air France dead 'to be recovered'
item.description: French officials say they could begin recovering victims of Air France's 2009 Rio plane crash within weeks, days after wreckage was found.

item.title: Merkel ally quits as her deputy
item.description: Germany's Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle quits as head of the liberal Free Democrat Party (FDP) and as deputy to Chancellor Merkel.

item.title: Thousands are missing in Mexico
item.description: A Mexican human rights group says more than 5,000 people have been reported missing since the war on drugs began.

item.title: Guatemala leader's divorce halted
item.description: A Guatemalan court puts the first couple's divorce on hold after complaints it is aimed at bypassing rules banning close relatives from succeeding the president.

item.title: Yemeni forces fire on protesters
item.description: At least 15 people are shot dead and dozens injured when troops open fire on a protest in the Yemeni city of Taiz, medical sources say.

item.title: 'Abducted' Gazan on Hamas charges
item.description: An Israeli court charges a Gaza engineer, allegedly abducted by Israeli agents in Ukraine, with running a training academy for Hamas.

item.title: Afghan 'policeman' kills Nato duo
item.description: Two Nato soldiers are shot dead in northern Afghanistan, with some officials saying the gunman was an Afghan border policeman.

item.title: Police dispel Bangladesh protest
item.description: Police disperse angry blockades, but the country is shut down by a strike enforced by Islamic groups protesting against equal property rights for women.

item.title: US official denies BP Gulf deal
item.description: US interior secretary Ken Salazar rejects claims that BP has reached an agreement to restart drilling for oil in the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: Cracks in three other US planes
item.description: Small cracks are found in three more Southwest Airlines planes after a hole in a cabin roof on Friday forced an emergency landing, officials say.

item.title: Mortgage pay-off at a new record
item.description: Homeowners paid off their mortgage borrowings by a record amount last year, Bank of England figures show.

item.title: Vodafone agrees £7bn Vivendi deal
item.description: Vodafone sells its 44% stake in French mobile phone operator SFR to Vivendi for 7.95bn euros (£7bn).

item.title: Brent crude oil at $120 a barrel
item.description: Oil prices hit two-and-a-half year highs as worries continue about supply from oil producing nations.

item.title: Minister defends 'Thatcher' claim
item.description: Greg Barker hits back after being attacked by Labour for telling a US audience the coalition is "making cuts that Margaret Thatcher could only have dreamt of".

item.title: Sickness benefit crackdown begins
item.description: The 1.5 million people who claim incapacity benefit will start to receive letters this week asking them to be tested on their ability to work.

item.title: Dissidents 'fighting useless war'
item.description: Those who murdered PSNI officer Ronan Kerr are waging "a useless war against peace", the NI Deputy First Minister Martin McGuiness says.

item.title: Autistic brains work differently
item.description: People with autism use their brains differently from other people, which may be why some have extraordinary abilities, according to new research.

item.title: Alzheimer's linked to more genes
item.description: More genes which increase the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease have been identified, scientists say.

item.title: Cancer charity 'tidies' Wikipedia
item.description: The charity Cancer Research UK is updating pages on Wikipedia to improve accuracy and clarity.

item.title: Gove wants surprise school checks
item.description: The schools watchdog Ofsted should carry out no-notice inspections to stop schools in England hiding bad behaviour, Education Secretary Michael Gove says.

item.title: Britain's pupils 'are bad losers'
item.description: A survey suggests UK schoolchildren are bad sports and find it difficult to lose graciously at games.

item.title: Mothers fighting Sure Start cuts
item.description: Mothers take their battle against cuts to Sure Start Children's Centres to Downing Street.

item.title: Clean up begins after site attack
item.description: The massive 'Lizamoon' attack has ensnared relatively few victims despite hitting thousands of websites.

item.title: Millions caught in e-mail breach
item.description: An attack on the world's biggest e-mail marketing firm has netted hackers millions of useful names and addresses.

item.title: Privacy group wants Google cash
item.description: US privacy group asks for $1.75m in settlement over Google's ill-fated Buzz service.

item.title: UK base for giant radio telescope
item.description: The Jodrell Bank Observatory in Cheshire will be the headquarters for a £1.3bn project to build the world's biggest radio telescope.

item.title: Glacier melt 'fastest for years'
item.description: Melting mountain glaciers are making sea levels rise faster now than at any time in the last 350 years, say experts from Aberystwyth and Exeter.

item.title: Dark feathers make healthy birds
item.description: Urban pigeons with dark feathers have stronger immune systems and are better able to fight off parasites, a study reveals.

item.title: Boyle's Katie Price joke censured
item.description: Media regulator Ofcom upholds 500 complaints against comedian Frankie Boyle and Channel 4 over "offensive" jokes about model Katie Price and son Harvey.

item.title: Al Fayed defends Jackson statue‎
item.description: Fulham chairman Mohammed Al Fayed tells fans they can "go to hell" if they do not appreciate a new Michael Jackson statue at Craven Cottage stadium.

item.title: Triptych sets Chinese art record
item.description: A three-panel oil painting by artist Zhang Xiaogang sells for 79m Hong Kong dollars (£6.3m) - a record auction price for Chinese contemporary art.

item.title: Who is Moussa Ibrahim?
item.description: His daily appearances in front of the world's media have made Moussa Ibrahim a familiar face, but how much do we really know about him?

item.title: Royal wedding watch
item.description: As the big day nears, the internet is abuzz with royal wedding stories. Keeping close tabs on them is our wedding fanatic.

item.title: Still America's most hated family?
item.description: After tales of defections, Louis Theroux investigates what's up with America’s most hated family.

item.title: VIDEO: Live: Detention of terror suspects committee
item.description: MPs and Peers are taking evidence on pre-charge detention proposals.

item.title: VIDEO: Live: Debate on violence against women
item.description: MEPs are debating a report by the Women's Rights Committee that calls for increased prosecution rates for violence against women.

item.title: VIDEO: Live: Statement on NHS reforms
item.description: Earl Howe is repeating a statement made earlier in the Commons on the government's proposed NHS reforms.

item.title: Test tube miracles
item.description: 25 years of IVF treatment at one of the UK's first dedicated centres

item.title: VIDEO: Training to fight for Libya's rebel army
item.description: Libyan rebels are continuing their fight against those loyal to Col Gaddafi, but many of their number have little or no training.

item.title: VIDEO: Defence cuts: 'Fewer personnel are needed'
item.description: Some 1,600 Navy personnel and 1,000 soldiers are to be laid off in the first round of redundancies from the Armed Forces, the government says.

item.title: VIDEO: Woman survives six-storey car plunge
item.description: An Australian woman has survived a six storey fall from a parking garage in Melbourne.

item.title: VIDEO: NI leaders vow to find PC's killers
item.description: Political leaders from Northern Ireland have pledged unity, and vowed to catch the killers of PC Ronan Kerr

item.title: VIDEO: Carpenter murdered two ex-girlfriends
item.description: A carpenter has been found guilty of murdering two former girlfriends, Melissa Halstead and Paula Fields, and throwing their mutilated bodies in canals.

item.title: VIDEO: Protesters change clothes during demo
item.description: The Metropolitan Police has released CCTV footage of protesters changing out of black clothes during last month's demonstrations in London.

item.title: VIDEO: How much is a first class stamp?
item.description: Members of the public talk to the BBC about how much they think one first class stamp costs.

item.title: VIDEO: Fulham fans react to Jackson statue
item.description: Statue of Michael Jackson unveiled at Fulham FC by owner Mohammed Al Fayed receives mixed reactions from fans

item.title: VIDEO: Statement on state pension changes
item.description: Live coverage from the House of Commons.

item.title: Calling security
item.description: What's it really like being a bodyguard?

item.title: Expert view
item.description: Fukushima shows that renewable energy is the way to go

item.title: DIY film-making
item.description: The rise of the user-generated feature

item.title: Q&A
item.description: How incapacity benefit is changing from this week

item.title: R.I.P. Daily Sport
item.description: Demise of an infamous newspaper

item.title: Rival bible
item.description: Do atheists need their own Good Book?
